detailed_translations.english: a plaintive sound is high, like someone crying, and sounds sad

name: plastic
trans: adj. capable of adapting to varying conditions 可塑的
adj. not real or sincere 做作的

sentences.english: a plastic spoon
sentences.chinese: 塑料汤匙

sentences.english: plastic bags
sentences.chinese: 塑料袋

detailed_translations.english: made of plastic

name: platitudinous
trans: adj. having the characteristics of a platitude 陈腐的

sentences.english: It has lived because readers appreciate a refreshing stimulus, an irreverent reminder that they live in a world of platitudinous thinking, cheap moralizing, and foolish philosophy.
sentences.chinese: 它的存在是因为读者欣赏使人耳目一新的刺激，毫不客气地提醒他们活在一个思相陈腐、道德低廉、哲学荒谬的世界里。

name: plausible
trans: adj. believable or realistic 真实的
adj. superficially fair, reasonable, or valuable but often specious 看似真实（但实际虚假）

sentences.english: His story certainly sounds plausible.
sentences.chinese: 他的叙述听上去当然很合理。

sentences.english: a plausible explanation
sentences.chinese: 说得过去的解释

detailed_translations.chinese: 似有道理的， 似乎正确的， 貌似可信的
detailed_translations.english: reasonable and likely to be true or successful

name: plentiful
trans: adj. containing or giving large amounts of something 充足的

sentences.english: a plentiful supply of food
sentences.chinese: 食物的大量供应

detailed_translations.english: more than enough in quantity

name: plethora
trans: n. excess, superfluity 过量

sentences.english: a plethora of suggestions
sentences.chinese: 一大堆建议

detailed_translations.chinese: 过多；过剩；[医] 多血症
detailed_translations.english: a very large number of something, usually more than you need

name: plodding
trans: adj. unexciting 单调乏味的

name: plummet
trans: v. to fall or drop suddenly in amount, value, etc. （数量，价值等）下跌

sentences.english: House prices have plummeted down.
sentences.chinese: 房价已经暴跌。

detailed_translations.chinese: 垂直落下；（价格、水平等）骤然下跌
detailed_translations.english: to suddenly and quickly decrease in value or amount

name: pointless
trans: adj. having no meaning, purpose, or effect 无意义的

sentences.english: Life just seemed pointless to me.
sentences.chinese: 生活对我来说简直没什么意义。

sentences.english: a pointless quarrel
sentences.chinese: 无谓的争吵

detailed_translations.english: worthless or not likely to have any useful result

name: polemic
trans: n. a strong written or spoken attack against someone else’s opinions, beliefs, practices, etc. 猛烈抨击
n. the art or practice of using language to defend or harshly criticize something or someone 态度鲜明（支持或者批评）

sentences.english: Before long, the dispute degenerated into fierce polemics.
sentences.chinese: 不久争论就演变为激烈的论战。

detailed_translations.english: a written or spoken statement that strongly criticizes or defends a particular idea, opinion, or person

name: polymath
trans: n. someone who knows a lot about many different things 博学者

sentences.english: Mr English, an associate editor of the Guardian, is a polymath who wears his learning lightly.
sentences.chinese: 英格力士先生是《卫报》的副编辑，是一位略显才华的博学者。

sentences.english: Shen Kuo (1031~1095) was a Chinese scientist, polymath, general, diplomat, and financial officer who was the inventor of compasses for navigation.
sentences.chinese: 沈括（1031~1095 ），科学家、博学者、将军、外交家、财务官员，发明了指南针。

sentences.english: Explorer, , polymath, friend of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Thomas Jefferson and Simon Bolívar, Alexander von Humboldt was one of the greatest scientists of the 19th century.
sentences.chinese: 探险家，博学者，歌德、杰弗逊和玻利瓦尔的朋友，洪堡是十九世纪最伟大的科学家之一，他的想法至今都没有过时。

detailed_translations.english: someone who has a lot of knowledge about many different subjects

name: ponder
trans: v. to think about or consider carefully 深思熟虑

sentences.english: He continued to ponder the problem as he walked home.
sentences.chinese: 他一边往家走一边继续思考那个问题。

detailed_translations.english: to spend time thinking carefully and seriously about a problem, a difficult question, or something that has happened

name: porous
trans: adj. having small holes that allow air or liquid to pass through 多孔的
adj. easy to pass or get through 能渗透的

sentences.english: porous material
sentences.chinese: 渗透性材料

detailed_translations.english: allowing liquid, air etc to pass slowly through many very small holes

name: portend
trans: v. to give an omen or anticipatory sign of 预言

sentences.english: strange events that portend disaster
sentences.chinese: 预示着灾难的奇怪事件

detailed_translations.english: to be a sign that something is going to happen, especially something bad

name: posture
trans: n. the attitude a person or group has toward a subject 态度
v. to assume an artificial or pretended attitude 摆姿态

sentences.english: her upright posture
sentences.chinese: 她笔挺的姿势

detailed_translations.english: the way you position your body when sitting or standing

name: potential
trans: adj. capable of becoming real 可能的
n. a chance or possibility that something will happen or exist in the future 可能性
n. an ability that someone has that can be developed to help that person become successful 潜力

sentences.english: The company has identified 60 potential customers.
sentences.chinese: 该公司已确定了60位潜在的客户。

detailed_translations.english: likely to develop into a particular type of person or thing in the future
the possibility that something will develop in a particular way, or have a particular effect

name: pragmatic
trans: adj. dealing with the problems that exist in a specific situation in a reasonable and logical way instead of depending on ideas and theories务实的

sentences.english: Williams took a more pragmatic approach to management problems.
sentences.chinese: 威廉斯在管理问题上采用的是一种更务实的做法。

detailed_translations.chinese: 实际的；实用主义的；国事的
detailed_translations.english: dealing with problems in a sensible practical way instead of strictly following a set of ideas

name: preachy
trans: adj. trying to teach something in a way that is annoying or unwanted 爱说教的

name: precarious
trans: adj. not safe, strong, or steady 危险的，不稳固的

sentences.english: Her health remained precarious, despite the treatment.
sentences.chinese: 她尽管接受了治疗，但健康状况还是不稳定。

sentences.english: the company’s precarious financial position
sentences.chinese: 公司岌岌可危的财务状况

detailed_translations.english: a precarious situation or state is one which may very easily or quickly become worse

name: precede
trans: v. to happen, go, or come before 比...先发生

sentences.english: a type of cloud that precedes rain
sentences.chinese: 下雨前出现的一种云

sentences.english: Lunch will be preceded by a short speech from the chairman.
sentences.chinese: 午餐开始之前主席会发表一段简短的讲话。

sentences.english: The guard preceded them down the corridor.
sentences.chinese: 警卫带领他们穿过了走廊。

detailed_translations.english: to happen or exist before something or someone, or to come before something else in a series

name: precipitate
trans: v. to cause to happen quickly or suddenly 引发，加速
n. a solid substance that is separated from al liquid especially by a chemical process 沉淀
adj. happening very quickly or too quickly without enough thought or planning 冲动的，鲁莽的

sentences.english: The riot was precipitated when four black men were arrested.
sentences.chinese: 这场骚乱是因为四名黑人男子的被捕而突然引发的。

sentences.english: I don't think we should make precipitate decisions.
sentences.chinese: 我认为我们不应该做出仓促的决定。

detailed_translations.english: a solid substance that has been chemically separated from a liquid

detailed_translations.chinese: 使沉淀；促成；猛抛；使陷入
detailed_translations.english: to make something serious happen suddenly or more quickly than was expected

detailed_translations.chinese: 突如其来的；猛地落下的；急促的
detailed_translations.english: A precipitate action or decision happens or is made more quickly or suddenly than most people think is sensible

name: preclude
trans: v. to make impossible by necessary consequence: rule out in advance
排除，防止

sentences.english: rules that preclude experimentation in teaching methods
sentences.chinese: 禁止进行教学方法试验的规定

detailed_translations.english: to prevent something or make something impossible

name: precocious
trans: adj. exhibiting mature qualities at an unusually early age 早熟的

sentences.english: a precocious child who walked and talked early
sentences.chinese: 走路和说话都早的早熟儿童

detailed_translations.english: a precocious child shows intelligence or skill at a very young age, or behaves in an adult way – sometimes used to show disapproval in British English

name: preconception
trans: n. an idea or opinion that someone has before learning about or experiencing something directly  先入之见

sentences.english: Did you have any preconceptions about the sort of people who did computing?
sentences.chinese: 你对那些使用计算机的人有什么先入之见吗？

detailed_translations.english: a belief or opinion that you have already formed before you know the actual facts, and that may be wrong

name: precursor
trans: n. something that comes before something else and that often leads to or influences its development 先驱

sentences.english: Error is often the precursor of what is correct.
sentences.chinese: 错误常常是正确的先导。

sentences.english: Viewed as a precursor to a wider open data movement, it could be as important as any we have seen in the web era.
sentences.chinese: 它被视为更宽泛的数据开放运动的先导，它将像我们在互联网时代看到的所有重要的事物一样重要。

detailed_translations.english: something that happened or existed before something else and influenced its development

name: predate
trans: v. to exist or happen at an earlier time than 早于

sentences.english: His troubles predated the recession.
sentences.chinese: 他的麻烦早在经济衰退前就出现了。

detailed_translations.english: If you say that one thing predated another, you mean that the first thing happened or existed some time before the second thing

name: predilection
trans: n. a natural liking for something 偏爱

sentences.english: ...his predilection for fast cars and fast horses.
sentences.chinese: ...他对跑车和骏马的偏爱。

detailed_translations.english: if you have a predilection for something, especially something unusual, you like it very much

name: predominant
trans: adj. more important, powerful, successful, or noticeable than other people or things 占优势的，主导的

sentences.english: the predominant group in society
sentences.chinese: 社会中的主导群体

sentences.english: In this painting, the predominant colour is black.
sentences.chinese: 这幅画的主色调是黑色。

detailed_translations.english: more powerful, more common, or more easily noticed than others

name: preeminent
trans: adj. more important, skillful, or successful than others 杰出的，卓越的

sentences.english: Bombastic boasts—"We are positioned to become the preeminent provider of XYZ"—do not constitute a position.
sentences.chinese: 言过其实的自夸——“我们定位于成为XYZ的卓越供应商”——并不能构建其地位。

sentences.english: And there is every reason to think America will once again regain its preeminent role as an American powerhouse.
sentences.chinese: 我们也完全有理由相信，美国将再次赢得美利坚强国的卓越地位。

sentences.english: Sweden cars are extremely prestigious and reliable in the world for its preeminent safety performance, including SAAB.
sentences.chinese: 瑞典制造的轿车在世界上最为有口皆碑的是其超群的安全性能，萨博也不例外。

name: prefigure
trans: v. to show or suggest something that will happen or exist at a future time 预示

sentences.english: The wall through Berlin was finally ruptured, prefiguring the reunification of Germany.
sentences.chinese: 柏林墙终于倒塌了，预示着德国的重新统一。

detailed_translations.english: to be a sign that something will happen later

name: prejudice
trans: n. a feeling of like or dislike for someone or something especially when it is not reasonable or logical 偏见
n. preconceived judgment or opinion 先入之见

sentences.english: Women still face prejudice in the workplace.
sentences.chinese: 女性在职场中仍然面临歧视。

sentences.english: It takes a long time to overcome these kinds of prejudices.
sentences.chinese: 战胜这些偏见需要假以时日。

sentences.english: There was concern that reports in the media would prejudice the jury.
sentences.chinese: 有人担心媒体的报道会影响陪审团的公正性。

detailed_translations.english: an un-reasonable dislike and distrust of people who are different from you in some way, especially because of their race, sex, religion etc – used to show disapproval
to influence someone so that they have an unfair or unreasonable opinion about someone or something

name: preoccupy
trans: v. to be thought about or worried about by (someone) very often or constantly 使全神贯注

sentences.english: But it is not hearts and minds in Kabul and Kandahar that most preoccupy the PM now, but hearts and minds much closer to home.
sentences.chinese: 但如今在首相的心中，最值得全神贯注的地方显然不在喀什穆和坎大哈，而是在国内。

detailed_translations.english: if something preoccupies someone, they think or worry about it a lot

name: presage
trans: v. to give or be a sign of 预示

sentences.english: In dreams one may presage the future.
sentences.chinese: 一个人能从梦中预感将来。

detailed_translations.english: to be a sign that something is going to happen, especially something bad

name: prescient
trans: adj. able to know or predict what was going to happen in the future 有预知能力的

sentences.english: ...an eerily prescient comedy about a populist multimillionaire political candidate.
sentences.chinese: ...围绕一位身价数百万的民粹主义政治候选人的一部喜剧，其预见性近乎诡异。

detailed_translations.english: able to imagine or know what will happen in the future

name: prescriptive
trans: adj. giving exact rules, directions, or instructions about how you should do something 指定的，规定的

sentences.english: prescriptive teaching methods
sentences.chinese: 规定的教学方法

detailed_translations.english: saying how something should or must be done, or what should be done

name: preside
trans: v. to be in charge of something 主持

sentences.english: I shall be pleased to preside at your meetings.
sentences.chinese: 我很高兴主持你们的会议。

sentences.english: Mr Justice Waller, presiding judge for the northeast
sentences.chinese: 沃勒法官，东北地区的首席法官

detailed_translations.english: to be in charge of a formal event, organization, ceremony etc

name: pressing
trans: adj. urgently important 紧迫的，重要的

sentences.english: The CD, released in October, sold out a first pressing of 1,500 in just four months.
sentences.chinese: 这张光盘发行于10月份，第一批压制的1,500张仅仅四个月就销售一空。

detailed_translations.english: a thing or group of things, especially records or CDs, that have been made by pressing plastic or metal into shape
needing to be discussed or dealt with very soon

name: prestige
trans: n. the respect and admiration that someone or something gets for being successful or important 威望

sentences.english: The king wanted to enhance his prestige through war.
sentences.chinese: 国王想通过战争来提高自己的威信。

sentences.english: This little-known British firm has now gained considerable prestige .
sentences.chinese: 这家名不见经传的英国公司如今已经声名鹊起。

sentences.english: the personal prestige attached to owning a large property
sentences.chinese: 拥有大房子所带来的体面

detailed_translations.english: the respect and admiration that someone or something gets because of their success or important position in society

name: preternatural
trans: adj. very unusual in a way that does not seem natural 异乎寻常的

sentences.english: He felt possessed of a preternatural strength and fearlessness.
sentences.chinese: 他感到自己拥有异乎寻常的力量和勇气。

detailed_translations.english: beyond what is usual or normal

name: pretext
trans: n. a reason that you give to hide your real reason for doing something
借口

sentences.english: He’ll phone on some pretext or other.
sentences.chinese: 他会以这样或那样的理由打电话的。

detailed_translations.english: a false reason given for an action, in order to hide the real reason

name: prevail
trans: v. to be usual, common, or popular 流行
v. to defeat an opponent especially in a long or difficult contest 占优势

sentences.english: 英文编辑：the economic conditions which prevail in England and Wales
sentences.chinese: 英格兰和威尔士普遍的经济状况

sentences.english: Justice will prevail.
sentences.chinese: 正义终将获胜。

detailed_translations.english: if a belief, custom, situation etc prevails, it exists among a group of people at a certain time

name: prevalent
trans: adj. accepted, done, or happening often or over a large area at a particular time 流行的，普遍的

sentences.english: the prevalent belief in astrology
sentences.chinese: 对占星术的普遍相信

detailed_translations.english: common at a particular time, in a particular place, or among a particular group of people

name: prevaricate
trans: v. to deviate from the truth 闪烁其词

sentences.english: ‘I’m not sure,’ he prevaricated.
sentences.chinese: “我不肯定。”他支支吾吾道。

detailed_translations.chinese: 搪塞；支吾其辞，闪烁其辞
detailed_translations.english: to try to hide the truth by not answering questions directly

name: primitive
trans: adj. of, belonging to, or seeming to come from an early time in the very ancient past 原始的
adj. very simple and basic 初级的，简陋的

sentences.english: a primitive society
sentences.chinese: 原始社会

sentences.english: a primitive nomadic tribe
sentences.chinese: 原始的游牧部落

sentences.english: the tools used by primitive man
sentences.chinese: 原始人所用的工具

sentences.english: primitive art
sentences.chinese: 原始艺术

sentences.english: The first station buildings were quite primitive.
sentences.chinese: 最初的车站建筑很简陋。

detailed_translations.chinese: 原始的；简单的；简单的，简陋的
detailed_translations.english: belonging to a simple way of life that existed in the past and does not have modern industries and machines

name: pristine
trans: adj. belonging to the earliest period or state 原始的
adj. not spoiled, corrupted, or polluted 崭新的

sentences.english: a pristine white shirt
sentences.chinese: 非常干净的白衬衫

name: privilege
trans: n. a right or immunity granted as a peculiar benefit, advantage, or favor
特权

sentences.english: He had no special privileges and was treated just like every other prisoner.
sentences.chinese: 他不享受特权，待遇和任何其他犯人一样。

detailed_translations.english: a special advantage that is given only to one person or group of people

name: probity
trans: n. the quality of a person who is completely honest 诚实，正直

sentences.english: I have always found Bentner to be a model of probity in our dealings.
sentences.chinese: 在我们的交往中，我一贯认为班特纳是诚实的典范。

detailed_translations.english: complete honesty

name: proclaim
trans: v. to say or state in a public, official, or definite way 宣布
v. to show clearly 表明

sentences.english: The President proclaimed the republic’s independence.
sentences.chinese: 总统宣布共和国独立。

detailed_translations.chinese: 宣告，公布；声明；表明；赞扬
detailed_translations.english: to say publicly or officially that something important is true or exists

name: proclivity
trans: n. a strong natural liking for something that is usually bad 倾向，嗜好

sentences.english: his sexual proclivities
sentences.chinese: 他的性倾向

detailed_translations.english: a tendency to behave in a particular way, or to like a particular thing – used especially about something bad

name: prodigious
trans: adj. extraordinary in bulk, quantity, or degree 巨大的

sentences.english: the artist’s prodigious output
sentences.chinese: 那位艺术家惊人的高产

detailed_translations.chinese: 惊人的，异常的，奇妙的；巨大的
detailed_translations.english: very large or great in a surprising or impressive way

name: profess
trans: v. to say or declare openly 公开宣称
v. to believe in (a particular religion) 信奉

sentences.english: She professed to hate her nickname.
sentences.chinese: 她声称讨厌她的绰号。

sentences.english: Why do organizations profess that they care?
sentences.chinese: 为什么一些组织声称他们关心呢？

detailed_translations.chinese: 表示， 承认； 宣称信仰
detailed_translations.english: If you profess to do or have something, you claim that you do it or have it, often when you do not

name: proficient
trans: adj. good at doing something 精通的

sentences.english: a proficient typist
sentences.chinese: 熟练的打字员

detailed_translations.english: able to do something well or skilfully

name: profitmonger
trans: n. 唯利是图的人，商人

name: profligate
trans: adj. wildly extravagant 挥霍的

sentences.english: profligate spending
sentences.chinese: 恣意挥霍

sentences.english: the profligate use of energy resources
sentences.chinese: 能源浪费

detailed_translations.chinese: 放荡的，不检点的；恣意挥霍的
detailed_translations.english: wasting money or other things in a careless way

name: profound
trans: adj. having or showing great knowledge or understanding 渊博的
adj. difficult to understand 深奥的
adj. coming from, reaching to, or situated at a depth 深刻的

sentences.english: a profound question
sentences.chinese: 深刻的问题

sentences.english: Jenner is a profound thinker.
sentences.chinese: 詹纳是个思想深刻的人。

detailed_translations.english: showing great knowledge and understanding

name: profusion
trans: n. a large amount of something 大量

sentences.english: ...a delightful river with a profusion of wild flowers along its banks.
sentences.chinese: ...一条令人愉悦的河，岸上开满了野花。

detailed_translations.english: a very large amount of something

name: proliferate
trans: v. to increase in number or amount quickly 激增

sentences.english: Computer courses continue to proliferate.
sentences.chinese: 计算机课程层出不穷。

detailed_translations.english: if something proliferates, it increases quickly and spreads to many different places

name: prolix
trans: adj. using too many words 冗长的

sentences.english: Everyone hates the prolix Gadaffi, particularly Arab despots who he routinely blasts as  “old women in robes,” “Zionist lackeys,” and “cowards and thieves.
sentences.chinese: 任何一个痛恨卡扎菲说话罗嗦的人，尤其是阿拉伯独裁君主们，他们例行公事似地攻击卡扎菲是“穿着长袍的老女人”，“犹太复国主义走狗”，和“懦夫和小偷”。

detailed_translations.english: a prolix piece of writing has too many words and is boring

name: prominent
trans: adj. easily notice or seen 显著的

sentences.english: a prominent Russian scientist
sentences.chinese: 杰出的俄罗斯科学家

sentences.english: The World Cup will have a prominent place on the agenda.
sentences.chinese: 世界杯赛将占据议程表的重要位置。

sentences.english: a prominent nose
sentences.chinese: 高鼻子

detailed_translations.english: important

name: promise
trans: n. an indication of future success or improvement 成功前景
n. a reason to expect that something will happen in the future 希望

sentences.english: If you make a promise, you should keep it.
sentences.chinese: 如果你许下一个诺言，你就应该遵守它。

sentences.english: Last night the headmaster promised a full investigation.
sentences.chinese: 校长昨晚允诺进行全面调查。

detailed_translations.english: a statement that you will definitely do or provide something or that something will definitely happen
to tell someone that you will definitely do or provide something or that something will happen

name: prompt
trans: v. to cause to do something 促使
adj. performed readily or immediately 迅捷的

sentences.english: Prompt action must be taken.
sentences.chinese: 必须立即采取行动。

sentences.english: Prompt payment is requested.
sentences.chinese: 请立即付款。

sentences.english: a prompt response
sentences.chinese: 迅速的答复

sentences.english: What prompted you to buy that suit?
sentences.chinese: 什么原因让你买下了那套西装？

detailed_translations.english: done quickly, immediately, or at the right time
to make someone decide to do something

name: prophetic
trans: adj. forestelling events 有预见的

sentences.english: It turned out to be a prophetic piece of journalism.
sentences.chinese: 事实证明那则新闻作出了正确的预言。

sentences.english: Lundgren’s warnings proved prophetic .
sentences.chinese: 事实证明伦德格伦的警告是有先见之明的。

detailed_translations.english: correctly saying what will happen in the future

name: propitious
trans: adj. likely to have or produce good results 吉利的

sentences.english: a propitious moment
sentences.chinese: 有利时机

detailed_translations.english: good and likely to bring good results

name: proponent
trans: n. a person who argues for or supports something 支持者

sentences.english: Halsey was identified as a leading proponent of the values of progressive education.
sentences.chinese: 哈尔西被认为是进步教育价值观的首要支持者。

detailed_translations.chinese: 支持者；建议者；提出认证遗嘱者
detailed_translations.english: someone who supports something or persuades people to do something

name: proprietary
trans: adj. used, made, or sold only by the particular person or company that has the legal right to do so 专利的
adj. kept private by an owner 私人独有的

sentences.english: a proprietary brand of insecticide
sentences.chinese: 专利品牌杀虫剂

sentences.english: proprietary software products
sentences.chinese: 专利软件产品

detailed_translations.chinese: 所有的；专利的；私人拥有的
detailed_translations.english: a proprietary product is one that is sold under a  trade name

name: prosaic
trans: adj. dull or ordinary 乏味的

sentences.english: a prosaic writing style
sentences.chinese: 乏味的写作风格

sentences.english: The reality, however, is probably more prosaic.
sentences.chinese: 然而，事实很可能更平淡无奇。

detailed_translations.chinese: 平凡的，乏味的；散文体的
detailed_translations.english: boring or ordinary

name: protean
trans: adj. able to change into many different forms or able to do many different things 变化多端的
adj. displaying great diversity or variety 多才多艺的

sentences.english: He is a protean stylist who can move from blues to ballads and grand symphony.
sentences.chinese: 他是一位富有变化的艺术家，能从布鲁斯转换到民谣以及雄壮的交响乐。

detailed_translations.chinese: 变化多端的， 多变的
detailed_translations.english: able to keep changing or to do many things

name: protract
trans: v. delay, defer 拖延
v. to extend forward or outward 延长

sentences.english: Delay always breeds danger; and to protract a great design is often to ruin it.
sentences.chinese: 推迟经常孕育危险；拖延一个伟大的工程常常意味着毁灭它。

sentences.english: To protract the suspense, he paused for a considerable period of time before telling us the result of the experiment.
sentences.chinese: 为了延长悬念，他在告诉我们实验结果之前停顿了相当一段时间。

detailed_translations.english: to lengthen or extend (a speech, etc); prolong in time

name: provenance
trans: n. the origin or source of something 起源

sentences.english: The provenance of the paintings is unknown.
sentences.chinese: 这些画出处不详。

detailed_translations.english: the place where something originally came from

name: provincial
trans: adj. not knowing or caring about people and events in other places
狭隘的
adj. of, relating to, or coming from a province 省的

sentences.english: a provincial election
sentences.chinese: 省级选举

sentences.english: the provincial government of Quebec
sentences.chinese: 魁北克省政府

detailed_translations.english: relating to or coming from a province

detailed_translations.chinese: 粗野的人；乡下人；外地人

name: provisional
trans: adj. serving for the time being 临时的，暂时的

sentences.english: a provisional government
sentences.chinese: 临时政府

sentences.english: We accept provisional bookings by phone.
sentences.chinese: 我们接受电话临时预约。

detailed_translations.english: likely or able to be changed in the future

name: provocative
trans: adj. causing discussion, thought, argument, etc. 引发的
adj. serving or tending to provoke, excite, or stimulate 挑衅的

sentences.english: a provocative act by a terrorist group
sentences.chinese: 恐怖团体的挑衅行为

sentences.english: She was accused of being deliberately provocative .
sentences.chinese: 她被指责故意挑衅。

detailed_translations.chinese: 挑衅的， 煽动的， 刺激的； 挑逗的
detailed_translations.english: provocative behaviour, remarks etc are intended to make people angry or upset, or to cause a lot of discussion

name: proximity
trans: n. the state of being near 接近

sentences.english: Here the rich and the poor live in close proximity (= very near to each other ) .
sentences.chinese: 在这里，富人和穷人比邻而居。

detailed_translations.english: nearness in distance or time

name: prudent
trans: adj. having or showing careful good judgment 审慎的

sentences.english: prudent house buyers
sentences.chinese: 谨慎的购房者

detailed_translations.english: sensible and careful, especially by trying to avoid unnecessary risks

name: prying
trans: adj. trying to find out about other people’s private lives 窥探的，爱打听的

name: pseudonym
trans: n. a name that someone uses instead of his or her real name 笔名，假名

sentences.english: Both plays were published under the pseudonym of Philip Dayre.
sentences.chinese: 两个剧本都是以菲利普·戴尔的笔名发表的。

detailed_translations.english: an invented name that a writer, artist etc uses instead of their real name

name: pugnacious
trans: adj. showing a readiness or desire to fight or argue 好斗的

sentences.english: The professor had been pugnacious and irritable.
sentences.chinese: 那位教授好斗而易怒。

detailed_translations.english: very eager to argue or fight with people

name: puncture
trans: v. to weaken, damage, or destroy suddenly or in a way that causes surprise or embarrassment 削弱，破坏
v. to make a hole in with a sharp point 刺孔

sentences.english: She was cycling home when she had a puncture .
sentences.chinese: 她骑车回家途中轮胎被扎破了。

detailed_translations.english: a small hole made accidentally in a tyre
if a tyre punctures, or if you puncture it, a small hole appears in it

name: purport
trans: v. to claim to be or do a particular thing when this claim may not be true  （假意）声称
n. the main or general meaning of something 意义

sentences.english: ...a book that purports to tell the whole truth.
sentences.chinese: …一本声称讲出全部真相的书。

detailed_translations.english: to claim to be or do something, even if this is not true
the general meaning of what someone says

name: purveyor
trans: n. one that purveys 供应商

name: purview
trans: n. an area within which someone or something has authority, influence, or knowledge 范围

sentences.english: This matter comes within the purview of the Department of Health.
sentences.chinese: 这件事属于卫生部的管辖范围。

detailed_translations.english: within or outside the limits of someone’s job, activity, or knowledge

name: put to rest
trans: phrase. 排除

name: quaff
trans: v. to drink a large amount of quickly 痛饮

sentences.english: Wedding guests quaffed champagne.
sentences.chinese: 婚礼上宾客开怀畅饮香槟酒。

detailed_translations.english: to drink a lot of something quickly

name: qualify
trans: v. to give the necessary skill or knowledge to do a particular job or activity 使有资格
v. to limit or modify the meaning of 限定

sentences.english: Free school lunches are given to children who qualify.
sentences.chinese: 符合条件的儿童可获得免费的学生午餐。

detailed_translations.english: to have the right to have or do something, or to give someone this right

name: qualm
trans: n. a feeling of uneasiness about a point 不安，疑虑

sentences.english: Despite my qualms, I took the job.
sentences.chinese: 尽管有些疑虑，我还是接受了那份工作。

sentences.english: The manager has no qualms about dropping players who do not perform well.
sentences.chinese: 对于放弃那些表现不好的队员，主教练并无不安。

detailed_translations.english: a feeling of slight worry or doubt because you are not sure that what you are doing is right

name: quash
trans: v. to suppress or extinguish summarily and completely 平息
v. to nullify especially by judicial action 否决

sentences.english: The High Court later quashed his conviction for murder.
sentences.chinese: 高等法院后来撤销了他犯有谋杀罪的判决。

sentences.english: The decision was quashed by the House of Lords.
sentences.chinese: 这个决议被上议院推翻了。

detailed_translations.chinese: 撤销；镇压；宣布无效；捣碎
detailed_translations.english: to officially say that a legal judgment or decision is no longer acceptable or correct

name: query
trans: v. to ask questions or express doubt about 质疑

sentences.english: Staff are always available to answer your queries.
sentences.chinese: 员工随时为您解答疑问。

detailed_translations.chinese: 疑问，质问；疑问号 ；[计] 查询
detailed_translations.english: a question that you ask to get information, or to check that something is true or correct
to express doubt about whether something is true or correct

name: quiescent
trans: adj. marked by inactivity or repose 不活跃的，静止的

sentences.english: ...a society which was politically quiescent and above all deferential.
sentences.chinese: ...一个遵循顺从至上及政治上平静的社会。

detailed_translations.chinese: 静止的；不活动的；沉寂的
detailed_translations.english: not developing or doing anything, especially when this is only a temporary state

name: quirky
trans: adj. odd or unpredictable in their appearance, character, or behavior. 奇怪的

name: quixotic
trans: adj. hopeful or romantic in a way that is not practical 不切实际的

sentences.english: This is a vast, exciting, and perhaps quixotic project.
sentences.chinese: 这是一个庞大、令人兴奋的项目，但可能有点不切实际。

detailed_translations.chinese: 唐吉诃德式的；狂想家的；愚侠的
detailed_translations.english: quixotic ideas or plans are not practical and are based on unreasonable hopes of improving the world

name: quotidian
trans: adj. ordinary or very common 普通的，常见的
adj. done each day 日常的

sentences.english: I had hopes of escaping my quotidian world.
sentences.chinese: 我曾希望能逃离自己的日常生活。

detailed_translations.english: Quotidian activities or experiences are basic, everyday activities or experiences

name: radical
trans: adj. having extreme political or social views that are not shared by most people 激进的
adj. very basic and important 基本的，根本的

sentences.english: They are proposing radical changes to the way the company is run.
sentences.chinese: 他们建议对公司经营模式进行重大改革。

sentences.english: a radical reform of the tax system
sentences.chinese: 税收制度的彻底改革

sentences.english: There are radical differences between the two organizations.
sentences.chinese: 这两个组织有着根本差异。

detailed_translations.chinese: 根本的，基本的；激进的，激进派的
detailed_translations.english: a radical change or difference is very big and important
someone who has new and different ideas, especially someone who wants complete social and political change

name: raillery
trans: n. friendly joking about or with somebody 开玩笑

name: rally
trans: v. to muster for a common purpose 团结，集会

sentences.english: After a shaky start, he rallied and won the title in style.
sentences.chinese: 虽然开局不顺，但他振作精神，最后漂亮地赢得了冠军。

sentences.english: The Tokyo stock market rallied later in the day.
sentences.chinese: 当天晚些时候东京股市止跌回升。

detailed_translations.chinese: 团结；重整；恢复；（网球等）连续对打
detailed_translations.english: to become stronger again after a period of weakness or defeat
a large public meeting, especially one that is held outdoors to support a political idea, protest etc

name: rampant
trans: adj. growing quickly and in a way that is difficult to control 泛滥的，疯长的

sentences.english: Pickpocketing is rampant in the downtown area.
sentences.chinese: 闹市区扒窃活动猖獗。

sentences.english: {"COLLOINEXA":["rampant inflation"]}
sentences.chinese: 失控的通货膨胀

detailed_translations.chinese: 猖獗的；蔓延的；狂暴的；奔放的
detailed_translations.english: if something bad, such as crime or disease, is rampant, there is a lot of it and it is very difficult to control

name: rant
trans: v. to talk loudly and in a way that shows anger 咆哮
v. to scold vehemently 严厉批评

sentences.english: As the boss began to rant, I stood up and went out.
sentences.chinese: 老板开始咆哮时，我站起来走了出去。

sentences.english: Even their three dogs got bored and fell asleep as he ranted on.
sentences.chinese: 甚至他们的3条狗在他不停地夸夸其谈时，都觉得厌烦并睡着了。

sentences.english: "Let's get it over and done with," he ranted.
sentences.chinese: “让我们就此了结这件事情，”他咆哮道。

sentences.english: Part I is a rant against organized religion.
sentences.chinese: 第一部分是对有组织的宗教的怒斥。

detailed_translations.english: If you say that someone rants, you mean that they talk loudly or angrily, and exaggerate or say foolish things
Rant is also a noun

name: rapacious
trans: adj. excessively grasping or covetous 贪婪的

sentences.english: rapacious landlords
sentences.chinese: 贪婪的房东

detailed_translations.english: always wanting more money, goods etc than you need or have a right to

name: rapprochement
trans: n. the development of friendlier relations between countries or groups of people who have been enemies 和解

sentences.english: Without settling this issue, Japan regards any form of rapprochement with North Korea as impossible.
sentences.chinese: 在日本看来，不解决这个问题，就不可能与朝鲜恢复任何形式的友好关系。

detailed_translations.chinese: 友好；恢复邦交；友善关系的建立
detailed_translations.english: the establishment of a good relationship between two countries or groups of people, after a period of unfriendly relations

name: rationale
trans: n. the reason or explanation for something 根本原因，逻辑依据

sentences.english: However, the rationale for such initiatives is not, of course, solely economic.
sentences.chinese: 但是，这些积极行动的根本原因当然不全是出于经济目的。

name: rattle
trans: v. to make nervous 使紧张，使不安

sentences.english: His mocking smile rattled her more than his anger.
sentences.chinese: 他那种嘲讽的微笑比他的愤怒更让她慌乱。

sentences.english: It was hard not to get rattled when the work piled up.
sentences.chinese: 工作积了一大堆，哪能不着急呢。

sentences.english: His confidence was rattled by the accident.
sentences.chinese: 这场事故动摇了他的自信。

detailed_translations.chinese: 使发出咯咯声；喋喋不休；使慌乱，使惊慌
detailed_translations.english: to make someone lose confidence or become nervous

detailed_translations.chinese: 喋喋不休的人；吓吱声，格格声
detailed_translations.english: a short repeated sound, made when something shakes

name: reactivate
trans: v. to make it work again after a period in which it has not been working
恢复

name: readable
trans: adj. clear and easy to read 清晰易懂的
adj. easy and enjoyable to read 可读性强的

sentences.english: This is a well researched and very readable book.
sentences.chinese: 这是一本研究深刻、可读性强的书。

detailed_translations.english: interesting and enjoyable to read, and easy to understand

name: realize
trans: v. to understand or become aware of 意识到
v. to achieve 实现

sentences.english: It took us a while to realize the extent of the tragedy.
sentences.chinese: 我们过了一段时间才意识到这场悲剧有多严重。

sentences.english: It was only later that I realized my mistake.
sentences.chinese: 我到后来才认识到自己的错误。

sentences.english: She never realized her ambition of winning an Olympic gold medal.
sentences.chinese: 中文例句:她一直未能实现赢取奥运会金牌的抱负。

detailed_translations.english: to know and understand something, or suddenly begin to understand it

name: rebuff
trans: v. to refuse in a rude way 拒绝

sentences.english: He received a humiliating rebuff from his manager.
sentences.chinese: 他遭到经理的断然拒绝，十分丢脸。

sentences.english: His proposals have already been rebuffed by the governor.
sentences.chinese: 他的建议已被州长拒绝了。

detailed_translations.chinese: 断然拒绝；回绝；漠不关心
detailed_translations.english: an unkind or unfriendly answer to a friendly suggestion or offer of help
If you rebuff someone or rebuff a suggestion that they make, you refuse to do what they suggest

name: recalcitrant
trans: adj. obstinately defiant of authority or restraint 倔强反抗的

sentences.english: a recalcitrant pupil
sentences.chinese: 一名不服管教的学生

name: recant
trans: v. to publicly say that you  no longer have an opinion or belief that you once had 宣布放弃

sentences.english: White House officials ordered Williams to recant.
sentences.chinese: 白宫官员命令威廉斯公开宣布放弃自己的观点。

detailed_translations.english: to say publicly that you no longer have a political or religious belief that you had before

name: recapitulate
trans: v. to give a brief summary of something 概括

sentences.english: Let's just recapitulate the essential points.
sentences.chinese: 让我们只概述一下基本要点吧。

detailed_translations.english: to repeat the main points of something that has just been said

name: recast
trans: v. remodel, refashion 改写

sentences.english: an attempt to recast the statement in less formal language
sentences.chinese: 用不太正式的语言改写声明的尝试

detailed_translations.english: to give parts in a play or film to different actors

name: reckon
trans: v. to regard or think of as 认为
v. estimate, compute 估计

sentences.english: ‘There’s nothing we can do about it.’ ‘You reckon (= used to express doubt or disagreement ) ?’
sentences.chinese: “这件事我们无能为力。”“是吗？”

detailed_translations.english: spoken to think or suppose something

name: recoil
trans: v. to quickly move away from something that is shocking, frightening, or disgusting 畏缩，后退

sentences.english: We recoil in horror from the thought of subjecting someone to extreme pain.
sentences.chinese: 想到要让一个人经受极度的痛苦，我们就会恐惧地退缩。

sentences.english: ...his small body jerking in recoil from the volume of his shouting.
sentences.chinese: …他小小身体在他大声的叫喊中畏缩地抽搐着。

detailed_translations.english: to move back suddenly and quickly from something you do not like or are afraid of
Recoil is also a noun

name: reconciliation
trans: n. the act of causing two people or groups to become friendly again after an argument or disagreement 和解

sentences.english: Her ex-husband had always hoped for a reconciliation.
sentences.chinese: 她的前夫一直想和她重归于好。

sentences.english: The treaty has brought a new spirit of reconciliation on both sides.
sentences.chinese: 条约使双方产生了新的和解精神。

sentences.english: The leadership announced a programme of national reconciliation (= an attempt by all sides to end a war or trouble in a country ) .
sentences.chinese: 领导层宣布了一个国内各方和解方案。

detailed_translations.english: a situation in which two people, countries etc become friendly with each other again after quarrelling

name: recondite
trans: adj. not understood or known by many people 晦涩难懂的

sentences.english: Her poems are modishly experimental in style and recondite in subject matter.
sentences.chinese: 她的诗在风格上时尚朦胧，在主题上深奥难懂。

detailed_translations.chinese: 深奥的；隐藏的；默默无闻的
detailed_translations.english: recondite facts or subjects are not known about or understood by many people

name: recrudescent
trans: adj. breaking out again 复发的

name: redouble
trans: v. to greatly increase the size or amount of 大量增加

name: redundant
trans: adj. repeating something else and therefore unnecessary 多余的

sentences.english: Seventy factory workers were made redundant in the resulting cuts.
sentences.chinese: 在继而发生的裁员中，70名工厂工人被解雇。

detailed_translations.chinese: 过剩的；失业的，被解雇的
detailed_translations.english: if you are redundant, your employer no longer has a job for you

name: regular
trans: adj. happening or done very often 常出现的

sentences.english: The company holds regular meetings with employees.
sentences.chinese: 公司定期召集雇员开会。

sentences.english: His breathing was slow and regular.
sentences.chinese: 他的呼吸缓慢而均匀。

sentences.english: Trains will run at regular intervals from 11 am to 4 pm.
sentences.chinese: 火车从上午11点到下午4点每隔一定时间开行。

sentences.english: We hear from him on a regular basis .
sentences.chinese: 我们定期收到他的来信。

sentences.english: He phones us every Sunday at six, regular as clockwork (= always at the same time ) .
sentences.chinese: 他每逢星期天6点钟打电话给我们，非常准时。

sentences.english: a regular job
sentences.chinese: 固定的工作

detailed_translations.english: happening every hour, every week, every month etc, usually with the same amount of time in between

name: rehabilitate
trans: v. to restore to a former state 恢复

sentences.english: a special unit for rehabilitating stroke patients
sentences.chinese: 协助中风患者康复的特殊病房

detailed_translations.chinese: 恢复地位；使残疾者恢复正常的生活
detailed_translations.english: to help someone to live a healthy, useful, or active life again after they have been seriously ill or in prison

name: rehash
trans: v. to present again in a slightly different form 老调重弹，炒冷饭

name: rein
trans: v. to control or direct with or as if with reins 统治，控制

sentences.english: Cord held the reins while the stallion tugged and snorted.
sentences.chinese: 当那匹牡马使劲挣扎，打着响鼻的时候，科德勒紧了缰绳。

detailed_translations.english: a long narrow band of leather that is fastened around a horse’s head in order to control it

detailed_translations.chinese: 勒缰使停步； 控制， 约束

name: reinvent
trans: v. to make major changes or improvements to 改造

name: rejection
trans: n. the action of rejecting 拒绝，排斥

sentences.english: They sent me a rejection letter.
sentences.chinese: 他们给我发了一封回绝信。

detailed_translations.english: the act of not accepting, believing in, or agreeing with something

name: relic
trans: n. something that is from a past time, place, culture, etc. 遗迹

sentences.english: Roman relics found in a field
sentences.chinese: 在野外发现的古罗马遗迹

detailed_translations.english: an old object or custom that reminds people of the past or that has lived on from a past time

name: relief
trans: n. the removal or reducing of something that is painful or unpleasant 解脱

sentences.english: Marijuana can provide pain relief for some cancer patients.
sentences.chinese: 大麻可以为一些癌症患者减轻疼痛。

sentences.english: money raised for the relief effort
sentences.chinese: 为赈灾筹集的钱款

detailed_translations.english: when something reduces someone’s pain or unhappy feelings

name: relinquish
trans: v. to give up 放弃

sentences.english: No one wants to relinquish power once they have it.
sentences.chinese: 人一旦有了权就不想放弃。

detailed_translations.english: to let someone else have your position, power, or rights, especially unwillingly

name: relish
trans: v. to enjoy or take pleasure in 享受

sentences.english: I relish the challenge of doing jobs that others turn down.
sentences.chinese: 我喜欢接受挑战做别人拒绝做的工作。

sentences.english: The three men ate with relish.
sentences.chinese: 那3个人吃得津津有味。

detailed_translations.english: to enjoy an experience or the thought of something that is going to happen
Relish is also a noun

name: reluctant
trans: adj. feeling or showing doubt about doing something: not willing or eager to do something 不情愿的

sentences.english: She gave a reluctant smile.
sentences.chinese: 她勉强笑了笑。

detailed_translations.english: slow and unwilling

name: remarkable
trans: adj. unusual or surprising: likely to be noticed 显著而惊讶的

sentences.english: She has made remarkable progress.
sentences.chinese: 她取得了显著的进步。

sentences.english: a remarkable coincidence
sentences.chinese: 不寻常的巧合

sentences.english: He’s a remarkable man .
sentences.chinese: 他是个了不起的人。

detailed_translations.english: unusual or surprising and therefore deserving attention or praise

name: remedy
trans: n. a medicine or treatment that relieves pain or cures a usually minor illness 治疗药物
n. a way of solving or correcting a problem 改进措施
v. to solve, correct, or improve 纠正，弥补

sentences.english: The problems in our schools do not have a simple remedy.
sentences.chinese: 我们学校的问题没有简单的解决办法。

sentences.english: To remedy the situation, the water must be chemically treated.
sentences.chinese: 为了改善这种情况，水必须进行化学处理。

detailed_translations.english: a way of dealing with a problem or making a bad situation better
to deal with a problem or improve a bad situation

name: remiss
trans: adj. not showing enough care and attention 懈怠的

sentences.english: I would be remiss if I did not do something about it.
sentences.chinese: 如果我对此不做点儿什么，就是懈怠。

detailed_translations.chinese: 怠慢的；迟缓的；不小心的
detailed_translations.english: If someone is remiss, they are careless about doing things that ought to be done

name: renaissance
trans: n. a period of new growth or activity 复兴

sentences.english: ...the Renaissance masterpieces in London's galleries.
sentences.chinese: …伦敦美术馆里文艺复兴时期的杰作。

detailed_translations.english: a new interest in something, especially a particular form of art, music etc, that has not been popular for a long period

name: render
trans: v. to reproduce or represent by artistic or verbal means 呈现，再现

sentences.english: an obligation to render assistance to those in need
sentences.chinese: 为有困难的人提供援助的义务

sentences.english: a bill of $3,200 for services rendered
sentences.chinese: 一张3,200美元服务费的账单

detailed_translations.english: to give something to someone or do something, because it is your duty or because someone expects you to

name: reprehensible
trans: adj. deserving very strong criticism 应受谴责的

sentences.english: I find their behaviour morally reprehensible .
sentences.chinese: 我认为他们的行为应该受到道德谴责。

detailed_translations.english: reprehensible behaviour is very bad and deserves criticism

name: repudiate
trans: v. to refuse to accept or support 拒绝承认
v. to refuse to having anything to do with 与...断绝关系

sentences.english: He repudiated all offers of friendship.
sentences.chinese: 他拒绝任何人给他的友谊。

detailed_translations.chinese: 拒绝；否定；批判；与…断绝关系；拒付
detailed_translations.english: to refuse to accept or continue with something

name: requisite
trans: adj. needed for a particular purpose 必需的

sentences.english: He lacks the requisite qualifications.
sentences.chinese: 他缺少必要的资历。

detailed_translations.chinese: 必备的，必不可少的；需要的
detailed_translations.english: needed for a particular purpose
something that is needed for a particular purpose

name: resemblance
trans: n. the state of looking or being like someone or something else 相似

sentences.english: The resemblance between Susan and her sister was remarkable.
sentences.chinese: 苏珊和她的姐姐十分相像。

detailed_translations.english: the fact of being or looking similar to sb/sth

name: reserved
trans: adj. restrained in words and actions 保守的，话少的
adj. kept or set apart or aside for future or special use 预留的

sentences.english: He was unemotional, quiet, and reserved.
sentences.chinese: 他不动感情、安静而矜持。

detailed_translations.english: Someone who is reserved keeps their feelings hidden

name: resolve
trans: v. to find an answer or solution to 解决
v. to make a definite and serious decision to do something 决定
n. a strong determination to do something 决心

sentences.english: Barnet was desperate for money to resolve his financial problems.
sentences.chinese: 巴尼特急需钱来解决他的经济问题。

sentences.english: After the divorce she resolved never to marry again.
sentences.chinese: 离婚以后，她决心永不再嫁。

sentences.english: Recent events strengthened her resolve to find out the truth.
sentences.chinese: 最近发生的事件坚定了她找出真相的决心。

detailed_translations.english: to find a satisfactory way of dealing with a problem or difficulty
strong determination to succeed in doing something

name: resonate
trans: v. to have particular meaning or importance for someone 对某人有重要性
v. to continue to produce a loud, clear, deep sound for a long time 共振
v. to relate harmoniously 一致

sentences.english: The bass guitar began to thump so loudly that it resonated in my head.
sentences.chinese: 低音吉他开始砰然作响，震得我的脑袋嗡嗡的。

detailed_translations.english: if something such as an event or a message resonates, it seems important or good to people, or continues to do this

name: respite
trans: n. an interval of rest or relief 喘息

sentences.english: There was no respite from the suffocating heat.
sentences.chinese: 闷热的天气根本没有缓解。

sentences.english: SHADE, from the upper cantilevering storey, brings respite and is welcoming in this tropical region.
sentences.chinese: 阴影来自于上层的悬挑部分，在热带地区为小屋带来暂时的休息和欢迎。

sentences.english: It was quite different from the verdant surroundings that we were used to in Slovenia, and respite only came from stopping at the small towns and villages that we came across along the Adriatic coast.
sentences.chinese: 这和我们走过的斯洛文尼亚郁郁葱葱的环境很不一样，只有在走过亚得里亚海长长的海岸线上那些小镇和村庄时，我们才能得到暂时的休息。

name: responsive
trans: adj. quick to react or respond 反应敏捷的

sentences.english: I tried to get him talking about his problems, but he wasn’t very responsive .
sentences.chinese: 我试图让他谈谈他的问题，但他不是很愿意讲。

detailed_translations.english: eager to communicate with people, and to react to them in a positive way

name: restive
trans: adj. feeling bored or impatient while waiting for something to happen or change 躁动不安的

sentences.english: Republican leaders struggled to rule over increasingly restive populations.
sentences.chinese: 人民不满情绪与日俱增，共和党领导人的统治举步维艰。

detailed_translations.chinese: 不安静的， 不安宁的
detailed_translations.english: dissatisfied or bored with your situation, and impatient for it to change

name: restorative
trans: adj. having the ability to make a person feel strong or healthy again 恢复健康的

sentences.english: the restorative power of sleep
sentences.chinese: 睡眠的恢复功效

detailed_translations.english: making you feel healthier or stronger

name: restrain
trans: v. to prevent from doing something 阻止
v. to keep under control 控制

sentences.english: I had to restrain her from running out into the street.
sentences.chinese: 我只得阻止她跑到街上去。

sentences.english: Price rises should restrain consumer spending.
sentences.chinese: 价格上涨会抑制消费支出。

detailed_translations.english: to stop someone from doing something, often by using physical force

name: resurgent
trans: adj. experiencing or tending to bring about renewal or revival 复兴的

sentences.english: resurgent fascism
sentences.chinese: 再次抬头的法西斯主义

detailed_translations.english: growing and becoming more popular, after a period of quietness

name: retain
trans: v. to keep in a position, job, etc. 保持

sentences.english: You have the right to retain possession of the goods.
sentences.chinese: 你有权保留这些物品。

sentences.english: The state wants to retain control of food imports.
sentences.chinese: 政府想保留对食品进口的控制权。

detailed_translations.english: to keep something or continue to have something

name: reticent
trans: adj. not willing to tell people about things 缄默的

sentences.english: She is so reticent about her achievements.
sentences.chinese: 她对于自己的成就如此缄默。

detailed_translations.chinese: 沉默的；有保留的；谨慎的
detailed_translations.english: Someone who is reticent does not tell people about things

name: retreat
trans: n. movement away from a place or situation especially because it is dangerous, unpleasant, etc. 撤退

sentences.english: Napoleon’s retreat from Moscow
sentences.chinese: 拿破仑从莫斯科的撤退

sentences.english: The rebel forces are in full retreat (= retreating very fast ) .
sentences.chinese: 叛军全线溃退。

sentences.english: The bugler sounded the retreat (= gave a loud signal for retreat ) .
sentences.chinese: 司号兵吹响撤退号。

detailed_translations.english: a movement away from the enemy after a defeat in battle
to move away from the enemy after being defeated in battle

name: reverence
trans: n. honor or respect that is felt for or shown to 尊敬

sentences.english: We stand together now in mutual support and in reverence for the dead.
sentences.chinese: 出于相互支持和对逝者的敬意，我们现在站到了一起。

detailed_translations.english: great respect and admiration for someone or something

name: reverse
trans: v. to change to an opposite state or condition 转向，颠倒

sentences.english: Reverse the paper in the printer.
sentences.chinese: 把打印机中的纸翻过来。

sentences.english: The wrong attitude will have exactly the reverse effect.
sentences.chinese: 这种错误的态度会得到恰好相反的结果。

detailed_translations.english: if a vehicle or its driver reverses, they go backwards

detailed_translations.chinese: 反向的； 相反的； 颠倒的
detailed_translations.english: Reverse means opposite from what you expect or to what has just been described

detailed_translations.chinese: 撤销，废除；使完全相反，彻底转变；使反转，使次序颠倒
detailed_translations.english: to change something, such as a decision, judgment, or process so that it is the opposite of what it was before

detailed_translations.chinese: 相反情况，对立面；反面，背面，后面；损失，倒退
detailed_translations.english: the exact opposite of what has just been mentioned

name: revision
trans: n. a change or a set of changes that corrects or improves something 修订

sentences.english: I know I haven’t done enough revision for tomorrow’s exam.
sentences.chinese: 我知道我对明天的考试准备不足。

detailed_translations.english: the process of changing something in order to improve it by correcting it or including new information or ideas

name: revolutionary
trans: adj. causing or related to a great complete change 革命性的

sentences.english: The new cancer drug is a revolutionary breakthrough.
sentences.chinese: 这种抗癌新药是一个革命性突破。

sentences.english: a revolutionary new drug
sentences.chinese: 一种革命性的新药

detailed_translations.english: completely new and different, especially in a way that leads to great improvements
someone who joins in or supports a political or social revolution

name: riddle
trans: n. a mystifying, misleading, or puzzling question posed as a problem to be solved or guessed 谜

sentences.english: See if you can solve this riddle .
sentences.chinese: 看看你能不能猜出这个谜语。

detailed_translations.english: to solve, explain, or interpret (a riddle or riddles)

detailed_translations.chinese: 谜语；粗筛；谜一般的人、东西、事情等
detailed_translations.english: a question that is deliberately very confusing and has a humorous or clever answer

name: ridicule
trans: n. the act of making fun of someone or something in a cruel or harsh way 嘲弄
v. to laugh at and make jokes about in a cruel or harsh way 嘲笑

sentences.english: the ridicule of his peers
sentences.chinese: 他同龄人的奚落

sentences.english: The government’s proposals were held up to ridicule (= suffered ridicule ) by opposition ministers.
sentences.chinese: 政府的提案遭到反对党部长们的嘲笑。

sentences.english: He had become an object of ridicule among the other teachers.
sentences.chinese: 他成了其他教师嘲笑的对象。

detailed_translations.english: unkind laughter or remarks that are intended to make someone or something seem stupid
to laugh at a person, idea etc and say that they are stupid

name: rigor
trans: n. the quality or state of being very exact, careful, or strict 严格

sentences.english: We are not so much testing as proposal-thinning, and we can add rigor such as traceability and other documentation as the leading architectural candidates emerge.
sentences.chinese: 我们不像细化提议那样做太多测试，随着最主要的架构候选的出现，我们可以添加严密，如可溯性和其他文档。

sentences.english: The towers, not only ground the buildings with their visual weight, but they also contribute to the rigor of rhythmic play needed in such expansive internal spaces and environment.
sentences.chinese: 这些塔楼不仅利用其视觉上的厚重感将建筑物固定在地面上，还有助于生成这种开阔的内部空间和环境所需的严谨的韵律感。

name: ring true
trans: phrase. 听来真实

name: risible
trans: adj. deserving to be laughed at 可笑的

sentences.english: a risible suggestion
sentences.chinese: 可笑的建议

detailed_translations.chinese: 可笑的；爱笑的；引人笑的
detailed_translations.english: something that is risible is so stupid that it deserves to be laughed at

name: ritualize
trans: v. to make a ritual of 使...程式化

detailed_translations.chinese: 使仪式化, 奉行仪式主义
detailed_translations.english: to engage in ritualism or devise rituals

name: robust
trans: adj. strong and healthy 健壮的
adj. successful or impressive and not likely to fail or weaken 强有力的

sentences.english: a robust man of six feet four
sentences.chinese: 一个身高六英尺四英寸的壮汉

detailed_translations.english: a robust person is strong and healthy

name: routine
trans: adj. of a commonplace or repetitious character 平凡乏味的

sentences.english: John’s departure had upset their daily routine .
sentences.chinese: 约翰的离去打乱了他们的日常生活。

sentences.english: Try to get into a routine (= develop a fixed order of doing things ) .
sentences.chinese: 尽量养成一套习惯。

sentences.english: my daily exercise routine
sentences.chinese: 我每天的锻炼习惯

sentences.english: Dressing is a task which we do every day as a matter of routine (= done regularly and not unusual ) .
sentences.chinese: 穿衣打扮是我们每天必做的事情。

sentences.english: You mustn’t worry. These are just routine enquiries.
sentences.chinese: 你不必担心，这只是例行的询问。

detailed_translations.english: the usual order in which you do things, or the things you regularly do
happening as a normal part of a job or process

name: row
trans: n. a noisy disturbance or quarrel 争吵

sentences.english: a family row
sentences.chinese: 家庭争吵

sentences.english: He had just had a row with his wife.
sentences.chinese: 他刚刚和妻子吵了一架。

detailed_translations.english: a short angry argument, especially between people who know each other well

name: rudimentary
trans: adj. basic or simple 基本的
adj. not very developed or advanced 未完全发布的

sentences.english: Gradually, I acquired a rudimentary knowledge of music.
sentences.chinese: 我逐渐掌握了基本的音乐知识。

sentences.english: my rudimentary German
sentences.chinese: 我粗浅的德语

detailed_translations.chinese: 基本的；初步的；退化的；残遗的；未发展的
detailed_translations.english: a rudimentary knowledge or understanding of a subject is very simple and basic

name: rule out
trans: phrase. 排除

name: ruminate
trans: v. to think carefully and deeply about something 认真思考

sentences.english: One is to see whether you have any worry triggers and to distract yourself when you begin to ruminate.
sentences.chinese: 首先看看你自己是否有担忧的动机，如果当你自己出现“沉思”时，尽量分散自己的注意力。

sentences.english: “Some people prone to ruminate have basic problems pushing things out of consciousness once they get there,” she said.
sentences.chinese: 有些人陷入事情中时，倾向于反刍基本问题来把事情驱逐出脑海。

sentences.english: This is in part because real events can affect us in the real world, and in part because we tend to ruminate about the implications of real-world acts.
sentences.chinese: 原因部分是由于真实事件影响着现实世界中的我们，部分是因为我们倾向反复思考现实世界中行为的影响。

detailed_translations.english: to think carefully and deeply about something

name: sacrifice
trans: n. something given up or lost 牺牲

sentences.english: The minister stressed the need for economic sacrifice.
sentences.chinese: 部长强调了在经济上作出牺牲的必要性。

sentences.english: The workforce were willing to make sacrifices in order to preserve jobs.
sentences.chinese: 雇员为了保住饭碗情愿作出牺牲。

sentences.english: She brought three children up single-handedly, often at great personal sacrifice.
sentences.chinese: 她独自一人把三个孩子带大，常常需要作出巨大的个人牺牲。

sentences.english: They made sacrifices to ensure a good harvest.
sentences.chinese: 他们举行献祭以保丰收。

sentences.english: He sacrificed a promising career to look after his kids.
sentences.chinese: 他为了照看孩子牺牲了很有前途的事业。

detailed_translations.english: when you decide not to have something valuable, in order to get something that is more important
to willingly stop having something you want or doing something you like in order to get something more important

name: sacrosanct
trans: adj. too important and respected to be changed, criticized, etc. 神圣不可改变的

sentences.english: Weekends are sacrosanct in our family.
sentences.chinese: 在我们家，周末的时间是神圣不可侵犯的。

detailed_translations.chinese: 神圣不可侵犯的；极神圣的
detailed_translations.english: something that is sacrosanct is considered to be so important that no one is allowed to criticize or change it

name: safeguard
trans: v. to make safe or secure 保卫

sentences.english: International safeguards prevent the increase of nuclear weapons.
sentences.chinese: 国际安全条约防止核武器数量增加。

detailed_translations.chinese: [安全] 保护；保卫；保护措施
detailed_translations.english: a rule, agreement etc that is intended to protect someone or something from possible dangers or problems
to protect something from harm or damage

name: salient
trans: adj. very important or noticeable 显著的，重要的

sentences.english: the salient points of the report
sentences.chinese: 这份报告的要点

detailed_translations.english: the salient points or features of something are the most important or most noticeable parts of it

name: salubrious
trans: adj. making good health possible or likely 有益健康的

sentences.english: The lines between salubrious and unwholesome government information are not easy to draw.
sentences.chinese: 有益和有害的政府信息之间的界线并不那么容易划分。

sentences.english: His features were pretty yet, and his eye and complexion brighter than I remembered them, though with merely temporary lustre borrowed from the salubrious air and genial sun.
sentences.chinese: 他的相貌挺好看，眼睛和气色也比我所记得的有精神些，虽然那仅仅是从有益健康的空气与和煦的阳光中借来的暂时的光辉。

name: salutary
trans: adj. having a good or helpful result especially after something unpleasant has happened 有益的

sentences.english: I notice we have janitors and janitresses now in offices, and our young men unfortunately miss that salutary branch of business education.
sentences.chinese: 我注意到现在的办公室都配备了工友，这使我们的年轻人不幸丢掉了这个有益的企业教育的一个内容。

sentences.english: Already a celebrity in his field, this "salutary tyrant, " as Riboud called him, dictated "which books to read, what political ideas I should have, which museums and galleries to visit.
sentences.chinese: 这位被里布称为“有益的暴君”的摄影师当时已经是这一领域的名人，他规定了“我该看什么书，持有什么政治理念，去什么博物馆和画廊”。

detailed_translations.chinese: 有益的， 有益健康的
detailed_translations.english: a salutary experience is unpleasant but teaches you something

name: salvational
trans: adj. 救世主般的

name: sanctimonious
trans: adj. pretending to be morally better than other people 假装（比别人）圣洁的

sentences.english: sanctimonious politicians preaching about family values
sentences.chinese: 大谈家庭价值观的虚伪政客

detailed_translations.chinese: 假装虔诚的；假装圣洁的；假装诚实的
detailed_translations.english: behaving as if you are morally better than other people, in a way that is annoying – used to show disapproval

name: sanction
trans: n. an action that is taken or an order that is given to force a country to obey international laws by limiting or stopping trade with that country, by not allowing economic aid for that country, etc. （经济）制裁
v. to officially accept or allow 批准

sentences.english: a resolution to impose sanctions (= start using sanctions ) on DPRK
sentences.chinese: 对朝鲜实施制裁的决议

sentences.english: the threat of trade sanctions
sentences.chinese: 贸易制裁的威胁

sentences.english: The UN security council may impose economic sanctions .
sentences.chinese: 联合国安理会可能会实施经济制裁。

sentences.english: Any talk about lifting sanctions (= ending them ) is premature.
sentences.chinese: 现时就谈取消制裁为时过早。

detailed_translations.english: official orders or laws stopping trade, communication etc with another country, as a way of forcing its leaders to make political changes
to officially accept or allow something

name: sanguine
trans: adj. confident and hopeful 乐观的

sentences.english: a sanguine view
sentences.chinese: 乐观的态度

detailed_translations.chinese: 乐观的；满怀希望的；面色红润的
detailed_translations.english: happy and hopeful about the future

name: sanity
trans: n. the condition of having a healthy mind 精神正常
n. the condition of being based on reason or good judgment 通情达理

sentences.english: I began to doubt his sanity.
sentences.chinese: 我开始怀疑他是否神志正常。

sentences.english: She wondered if she was losing her sanity .
sentences.chinese: 她怀疑自己是否精神有问题。

detailed_translations.chinese: 心智健全，神智正常；判断正确
detailed_translations.english: the condition of being mentally healthy

name: sartorial
trans: adj. of or relating to clothes 裁缝的，制衣的

sentences.english: ...Sebastian's sartorial elegance.
sentences.chinese: ...塞巴斯蒂安衣着的优雅。

detailed_translations.english: Sartorial means relating to clothes and to the way they are made or worn

name: scant
trans: adj. very small in size or amount 缺乏的

sentences.english: The story has received scant attention in the press.
sentences.chinese: 这件事没在报界引起多少注意。

sentences.english: They produce goods with scant regard for quality.
sentences.chinese: 他们的产品不够重视质量。

detailed_translations.chinese: 不足的；缺乏的；勉强够的
detailed_translations.english: not enough

name: scarce
trans: adj. very small in amount or number 缺乏的

sentences.english: Food was often scarce in the winter.
sentences.chinese: 冬季常常粮食短缺。

sentences.english: There was fierce competition for the scarce resources .
sentences.chinese: 对这些紧缺资源的争夺非常激烈。

detailed_translations.chinese: 缺乏的， 不足的； 稀少的， 罕见的
detailed_translations.english: if something is scarce, there is not very much of it available

name: scaremonger
trans: n. one inclined to raise or excite alarms especially needlessly 危言耸听者

name: schism
trans: n. a division among the members of a group that occurs because they disagree on something 分裂

sentences.english: The church seems to be on the brink of schism.
sentences.chinese: 该教会看来处于分裂的边缘。

detailed_translations.english: the separation of a group into two groups, caused by a disagreement about its aims and beliefs, especially in the Christian church

name: scorn
trans: v. reject or dismiss as contemptible or unworthy 鄙视

sentences.english: Researchers greeted the proposal with scorn.
sentences.chinese: 研究者们对这个提议报以轻蔑的态度。

detailed_translations.english: the feeling that someone or something is stupid or does not deserve respect

detailed_translations.chinese: 轻蔑， 鄙视； 拒绝， 不屑
detailed_translations.english: to show that you think that something is stupid, unreasonable, or not worth accepting

name: scrutinize
trans: v. to examine carefully especially in a critical way 仔细检查

sentences.english: He scrutinized the document.
sentences.chinese: 他细阅了这份文件。

sentences.english: She scrutinized his face.
sentences.chinese: 她细细端详他的脸。

detailed_translations.english: to examine someone or something very carefully

name: secondhand
trans: adj. not original 间接的

sentences.english: They could afford a secondhand car, she thought.
sentences.chinese: 他们能买得起一辆二手车，她想。

sentences.english: I only heard about it secondhand.
sentences.chinese: 我只间接听说了这件事。

detailed_translations.chinese: 二手的；旧的；间接获得的；做旧货生意的
detailed_translations.english: Secondhand things are not new and have been owned by someone else

detailed_translations.chinese: 间接地；间接听来；以旧货
detailed_translations.english: Secondhand is also an adverb

name: secure
trans: v. to get secure usually lasting possession or control of 获得
adj. protected from danger or harm 安全的，牢固的

sentences.english: There are no secure jobs these days.
sentences.chinese: 如今已经没有铁饭碗了。

sentences.english: We want a secure future for our children.
sentences.chinese: 我们希望我们的孩子未来生活无虞。

sentences.english: United’s position at the top of the league seems relatively secure.
sentences.chinese: 联队在联赛中的头名位置似乎相对稳固。

detailed_translations.english: a situation that is secure is one that you can depend on because it is not likely to change
to make something safe from being attacked, harmed, or lost

name: self-aggrandizing
trans: adj. 自我扩张的（仅用于抽象事物）

name: self-defeating
trans: adj. 对自身不利的

name: self-effacing
trans: adj. not like talking about themselves or drawing attention to themselves
谦逊的，不出风头的

name: self-evident
trans: adj. clearly true and requiring no proof or explanation 不证自明的

sentences.english: self-evident truths
sentences.chinese: 不言自明的真相

detailed_translations.chinese: 不证自明的，不言而喻的
detailed_translations.english: clearly true and needing no more proof

name: self-perpetuating
trans: adj. 自续的

name: seminal
trans: adj. having a strong influence on ideas, works, events, etc., that come later 开创性的

sentences.english: a seminal study of eighteenth-century France
sentences.chinese: 对18世纪法国的开创性研究

detailed_translations.english: producing or containing  semen

name: senescence
trans: adj. the state of being old or the process of becoming old 衰老

name: sequential
trans: adj. of, relating to, or arranged in a particular order or sequence 连续的，顺序的

sentences.english: ...the sequential story of the universe.
sentences.chinese: ...宇宙的变迁史。

detailed_translations.english: relating to or happening in a sequence

name: sequester
trans: v. to set apart 隔绝

sentences.english: The jury were sequestered during the trial.
sentences.chinese: 审判期间，陪审团被隔离开来。

detailed_translations.chinese: 使隔绝；使隐退；没收，扣押
detailed_translations.english: to keep a person or a group of people away from other people

name: sever
trans: v. to put or keep apart 割断，断绝

sentences.english: Martin’s hand was severed in the accident.
sentences.chinese: 马丁的一只手在事故中被切断了。

sentences.english: a severed rope
sentences.chinese: 割断的绳子

detailed_translations.english: to cut through something completely, separating it into two parts, or to become cut in this way

detailed_translations.chinese: (Sever)人名；(俄)谢韦尔；(捷、塞、意、西、土、瑞典、罗)塞韦尔；(英)塞弗；(德)泽弗

name: shackle
trans: n. something that prevents people from acting freely 束缚
v. to put shackles on 束缚

name: shallow
trans: adj. penetrating only the easily or quickly perceived 肤浅的

sentences.english: a shallow river
sentences.chinese: 浅河

sentences.english: The lake is quite shallow.
sentences.chinese: 这湖很浅。

sentences.english: the shallow end of the pool
sentences.chinese: 游泳池的浅水区

sentences.english: Place the meat in a shallow dish.
sentences.chinese: 把肉放在一个浅盘里。

detailed_translations.english: measuring only a short distance from the top to the bottom

name: sham
trans: n. cheep falseness 假东西，赝品

sentences.english: The elections were a complete sham.
sentences.chinese: 这次大选完全是一场骗局。

detailed_translations.english: someone or something that is not what they are claimed to be – used to show disapproval
to pretend to be upset, ill etc to gain sympathy or an advantage
made to appear real in order to deceive people

name: shirk
trans: v. to avoid doing something that you are supposed to do 逃避

sentences.english: He was fired for shirking.
sentences.chinese: 他因偷懒被解雇了。

detailed_translations.english: to deliberately avoid doing something you should do, because you are lazy

name: shoddy
trans: adj. poorly done or made 粗制滥造的

sentences.english: shoddy journalism
sentences.chinese: 黑暗的新闻业

detailed_translations.english: made or done cheaply or carelessly

name: short-lived
trans: adj. living or lasting for a short time 短暂的

name: shortcoming
trans: n. an imperfection or lack that detracts from the whole 缺点

sentences.english: Peter was painfully aware of his own shortcomings.
sentences.chinese: 彼得痛苦地认识到了自己的短处。

detailed_translations.english: a fault or weakness that makes someone or something less successful or effective than they should be

name: shrewd
trans: adj. having or showing an ability to understand things and to make good judgments 精明的

sentences.english: Malcolm is a shrewd businessman.
sentences.chinese: 马尔科姆是个精明的商人。

sentences.english: She was shrewd enough to guess who was responsible.
sentences.chinese: 她很精明，一猜就知道是谁干的。

sentences.english: Capra looked at her with shrewd eyes.
sentences.chinese: 卡普拉眼神犀利地看着她。

detailed_translations.english: good at judging what people or situations are really like

name: shriek
trans: v. to make a loud, high-pitched cry 尖叫

sentences.english: They were dragged from their homes, shrieking and weeping.
sentences.chinese: 他们哭喊着被人从家里拖出去。

sentences.english: He shrieked in agony.
sentences.chinese: 他痛苦地尖叫起来。

detailed_translations.english: to make a very high loud sound, especially because you are afraid, angry, excited, or in pain
a loud high sound made because you are frightened, excited, angry etc

name: shrink
trans: v. to quickly move away from something shocking, frightening, or disgusting 退缩，回避
v. to become smaller in amount, size, or value 缩小，减少

sentences.english: I’m worried about washing that shirt in case it shrinks.
sentences.chinese: 我不太敢洗那件衬衫，怕它会缩水。

detailed_translations.chinese: 起皱； 收缩； 退缩， 畏缩
